segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā tisso bhagavato pitucchāputto sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamāroceti:
segments.en: Now at that time Venerable Tissa, the Buddha’s paternal cousin, informed several mendicants:

“Reverends, my body feels like it’s drugged. I’m disorientated, the teachings don’t inspire me, and dullness and drowsiness fill my mind. I live the spiritual life dissatisfied, and have doubts about the teachings.”

segments.pli: Atha kho sambahulā bhikkhū yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū bhagavantaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.

segments.pli: “āyasmā, bhante, tisso bhagavato pitucchāputto sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamāroceti:
Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantesi:
segments.en: So the Buddha said to a certain monk,

segments.pli: “ehi tvaṃ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena tissaṃ bhikkhuṃ āmantehī”ti.
segments.en: “Please, mendicant, in my name tell the mendicant Tissa that the Teacher summons him.”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yenāyasmā tisso tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ tissaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Tissa and said to him,

segments.pli: “Evamāvuso”ti kho āyasmā tisso tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ tissaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
segments.en: “Yes, reverend,” Tissa replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

segments.pli: “saccaṃ kira tvaṃ, tissa, sambahulānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ evamārocesi:
segments.en: “Is it really true, Tissa, that you informed several mendicants that

segments.pli: ‘api me, āvuso, madhurakajāto viya kāyo … pe …
segments.en: your body feels like it’s drugged …
and you have doubts about the teachings?”

segments.pli: rūpe avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa, tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: If you’re not rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
when you’re not rid of greed for form.
If you’re not rid of greed for feeling …

segments.pli: Yathā taṃ saṅkhāresu anigatarāgassa, viññāṇe avigatarāgassa avigatacchandassa avigatapemassa avigatapipāsassa avigatapariḷāhassa avigatataṇhassa, tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: consciousness, when that consciousness decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
when you’re not rid of greed for consciousness.

segments.pli: rūpe vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa, tassa rūpassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?
segments.en: If you are rid of greed, desire, fondness, thirst, passion, and craving for form, when that form decays and perishes, will it give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress?”
when you are rid of greed for form …

segments.pli: viññāṇe vigatarāgassa vigatacchandassa vigatapemassa vigatapipāsassa vigatapariḷāhassa vigatataṇhassa tassa viññāṇassa vipariṇāmaññathābhāvā uppajjanti sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā”ti?

segments.en: They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’
Suppose, Tissa, there were two people.

segments.pli: eko puriso amaggakusalo, eko puriso maggakusalo.
segments.en: One was not skilled in the path, the other was.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ so amaggakusalo puriso amuṃ maggakusalaṃ purisaṃ maggaṃ puccheyya.
segments.en: The one not skilled in the path would question the one skilled in the path,
‘Come, good man, this is the path.

segments.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi dvedhāpathaṃ, tattha vāmaṃ muñcitvā dakkhiṇaṃ gaṇhāhi.
segments.en: and you’ll see a fork in the road. Ignore the left, and take the right-hand path.

segments.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi tibbaṃ vanasaṇḍaṃ.
segments.en: and you’ll see a dark forest grove.

segments.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi mahantaṃ ninnaṃ pallalaṃ.
segments.en: and you’ll see an expanse of low-lying marshes.

segments.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi sobbhaṃ papātaṃ.
segments.en: and you’ll see a large, steep cliff.

segments.pli: Tena muhuttaṃ gantvā dakkhissasi samaṃ bhūmibhāgaṃ ramaṇīyan’ti.
segments.en: and you’ll see level, cleared parkland.’

segments.pli: Upamā kho myāyaṃ, tissa, katā atthassa viññāpanāya.
segments.en: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
And this is what it means.
‘A person who is not skilled in the path’ is a term for an ordinary uneducated person.

segments.pli: ‘Puriso maggakusalo’ti kho, tissa, tathāgatassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
segments.en: ‘A person who is skilled in the path’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
‘A fork in the road’ is a term for doubt.

segments.pli: ‘Vāmo maggo’ti kho, tissa, aṭṭhaṅgikassetaṃ micchāmaggassa adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: ‘The left-hand path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,

segments.pli: ‘Dakkhiṇo maggo’ti kho, tissa, ariyassetaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikassa maggassa adhivacanaṃ, seyyathidaṃ—
segments.en: ‘The right-hand path’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is,
‘A dark forest grove’ is a term for ignorance.

segments.pli: ‘Mahantaṃ ninnaṃ pallalan’ti kho, tissa, kāmānametaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
segments.en: ‘An expanse of low-lying marshes’ is a term for sensual pleasures.
‘A large, steep cliff’ is a term for anger and distress.

segments.pli: ‘Samo bhūmibhāgo ramaṇīyo’ti kho, tissa, nibbānassetaṃ adhivacanaṃ.
segments.en: ‘Level, cleared parkland’ is a term for extinguishment.
I’m here to advise you, to support you, and to teach you.”
That is what the Buddha said.

segments.pli: Attamano āyasmā tisso bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandīti.
segments.en: Satisfied, Venerable Tissa was happy with what the Buddha said.

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Tissa, the Blessed One’s paternal cousin, tells the monks that he is dissatisfied as a monk. When the Buddha hears of this, he calls Tissa to him, and questions him on the aggregates. As Tissa showed his understanding of each question, the Buddha praised him, lifting his spirits.
